projectDesc.p: This project DHARMA has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement no 809994).

prefixDef.p: Public URIs with the prefix bib to point to a Zotero Group Library named ERC-DHARMA whose data are open to the public.
Internal URIs using the part prefix to point to person elements in the DHARMA_IdListMembers_v01.xml file.

div.p:

babadan·, mata panas·, payaman·, buhara suvul·, buhara Uṇḍuḥ, buhara tṅaḥ, buhara hoya, buhara pa

naḍaḥ tan hana kantuna rīṅ irusan· kla-kla Ambǝl-ambǝl·, kasyan·, lǝt-lǝt·, bhaṇḍa kaṇḍi paliḍva parisukha §
saṅ amaṅan·, tahu lan vagalan· haryyas· kuluban· suṇḍa rumbaḥ Ityevamādi, tan hana kakuraṁ, maṅka
5
na taṁ haraṁ-haraṁ, ḍeṁ kakap·, kaḍivas·, taṅiri, hnus·, huraṁ, biluṁluṁ prakāra, paripūrṇna Ikā kabeḥ, muAṁ §
pāṇa siddhu mastava kiñca kilaṁ tvak· paripūrṇna Ikā kabeḥ, mataṅ yan· tan parāryyan· saṁ manaḍahakǝn tahapa
n·, mataṁṅ yan vijaḥ sira kabeḥ, muAṁ men-men·, si piatiṅhalan·, mabañol·, si pati bañcil·, muAṁ si bari
pacǝḥ, Atapukan·, si giraṁ hyasǝn·, matǝkapakǝn sira kabeḥ, dinmakan· kupaṁ, 2, sovaṁ-sovaṁ, I tlasnira ka
beḥ manaḍaḥ, maṅḍiri saṁ makudur vadihati patiḥ pramukha, kapuA manǝmbaḥ I sārah-araḥ śrī mahārāja, muAṁ ra§

tiṅkaḥ samya hajī vatu kura, //Ø//, Iṁ śaka, 1270, Ăṣāḍhā-māsa, tīthi, Ekădaśi śuklapakṣa, pā, va,
ca, vāra, juluṁ, //Ø// : :,

app.note: Cf. Kalimusan r3 for the same term. Compare the present list of functions (maṅilala) with that of Kalimusan. The list of the Watu Kura I inscription includes insertions of new terms (?).
There seems to be a problem with van Naerssen's numbering of the plates.

The passage of several lines from tumŭt krama onwards has a lose parallel in an inscription of Sindok. Compare with Paradah II, line 90ff: tumūt krama saṁ hana rikān piṅhai vahuta rāma kabayan muAṁ rāma tpi siriṁ kulapati punta matuha rarai laki-laki vadvan (91) kaniṣṭa-madhyamottama tan hana kantun ilu manaḍaḥ Iṁ paglaran iṁ pkan kinuR̥n-kuR̥n inaṁsəAn skul dākdannan hinirusan kla-kla Ambill-ambil ta(92)syan lid-lid tlu sanek paliddha takiḥ pariṅ suka varagalan saṅa-saṅān rumba-rumbaḥ kuluban tekis tumpuk-tumpuk ḍeṁ hanaṁ ḍeṁ hasin kakab (93) rumahan kadivas kavan huraṁ gtam biluṁluṁ laya-layar hala-hala hantiga Inari sunda, Atak pəhan tahu lan ginaṅannan haryyas piṇḍa gaṅan iṁ saro(94)n limas 12 len saṅkā rikaṁ Ivak knas prakāra Anaḍaḥ sira kabaiḥ yathāsukha maṅinuṁ siddhu ciñca tuAak pintiga sovaṁ vinuvuhan tambul inañjapan· (95) kuravu kurima, ...

div.p: Hail! Elapsed Śaka year 824, month of Śravaṇa, fifteenth tithi of the waxing fortnight, Paniron, Paiṅ‚ Tuesday, in the vuku Maḍaṅ Kuṅan, seventh karaṇa, position of the moon: pūrvasādha, declination: Śiva.

That was the time when the Great King, Lord rake of Vatu Kura, Prince Balituṅ, the Illustrious Īśvarakeśavotsavatuṅga, bestowed upon the village elders of Vatu Kura a demarcation fee of 1 māṣa kā for the place of his (i.e. Balituṅ's) ancestral foundation dharma paṅasthūlan. It is to be worshipped by the village elders of Vatukura every full moon of the month of Bhādrapada,

In addition, the irrigated rice fields, the dry rice fields, the wet rice fields, and the gardens, they are to contribute the sum of 1 māṣa in silver per head. The community duvan of Babadan is to contribute 3 māṣa. The village of Mata Panas is to contribute 1 māṣa of gold, 4 māṣa, Payaman 1 māṣa of gold, 4 māṣa, Buhara Suvul 5 māṣa, Buhara Uṇḍuh 3 māṣa, Buhara Təṅah 5 māṣa, Buhara Hoya 5 māṣa, Buhara Paṅanten 2 māṣa, Bareṅ 10 māṣa, also the floral-tribute lit. making of flowerbaskets is to be paid 2 māṣa ku and unpolished rice to the value of 1 ku per household lit. per door and moreover 1 māṣa ku and unpolished rice to the value of 1 ku per household for the Panaman festival on the day of the full moon in the month of Jyaiṣṭha. Further, 1 māṣa ku and unpolished rice to the value of 1 ku per household on the day of the full moon the month of Caitra.

Further, the ravi galuh the jewel-radiant sun? of Babadan is to give wooden buckets, salvers, the akṣenya of the god of the foundation, besides his head ornament. These constitute the offerings of the village elders to the god of the foundation. The remains (of the offerings) shall belong to the persons who take part in the work: those who officiate at the offerings, at the upakalpa sacred functions, those who sweep (the temple ground), the servants of the temple, the pasinghir, all the people of merit who guard the god. They shall have the remains. Moreover, the remains are to be used for the festive garments to be made by the village elders, viz. rings for the upper arm and the forearm and ornaments provided with the Śrī symbol in honour of the god of the foundation. ...
panīma: see other instances of payment of a demarcation fee?
dharmma paṅasthūlan: is this Balitung's deification temple?

First edited by J.L.A. Brandes , apparently based on autopsy of the plate; readings of small segments of text containing proper names and toponyms by L.-Ch. Damais () based on a mediocre eye-copy that he had been able to consult at the Archaeological Service; reproduction of Brandes’ edition, to which is added a translation into English, by H. B. Sarkar (). The text is re-edited by Arlo Griffiths without inspection of any reproduction, taking Brandes’ edition as base-text, with reinterpretation of the transliteration system according to DHARMA norms, and adoption of new readings proposed by Damais.

bibl.note: Nakada refers to 1082, but the paragraph in question concerns another item from the Dieduksman collection; Nakada’s reference to 245 is likewise a red herring, as the Guntur inscription is intended there.
